natural problem: Let $p(x) = 2x - 7$ and $q(x) = 3x - b$.  If $p(q(4)) = 7$, what is $b$?
natural solution: Since $q(4) = 3\cdot 4 - b = 12-b$, we can write $p(q(4)) = 7$ as $p(12-b) = 7$. Since $p(x) = 2x-7$, we have $p(12-b) = 2(12-b) - 7 = 17 - 2b$.
Substituting this into $p(12-b) = 7$ gives $17-2b =7$, from which we have $b = \boxed{5}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x b :: real and p q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = 2 * x - 7"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. q x = 3 * x - b"
and h2 : "p (q 4) = 7"
shows  "b = 5"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 ### Proof
 Since $q(4) = 3\cdot 4 - b = 12-b$, we can write $p(q(4)) = 7$ as $p(12-b) = 7$. Since $p(x) = 2x-7$, we have $p(12-b) = 2(12-b) - 7 = 17 - 2b$.
 Substituting this into $p(12-b) = 7$ gives $17-2b =7$, from which we have $b = \boxed{5}$.
 *)

fixes x b :: real and p q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. p x = 2 * x - 7"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. q x = 3 * x - b"
and h2 : "p (q 4) = 7"
shows  "b = 5"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
